provenance.note: Possibly inherited by Catherine Blake upon William Blake's death in 1827; possibly acquired by Frederick Tatham upon Catherine Blake's death in 1831; possibly one of the two works "in colours" sold anonymously, Sotheby's, 29 April 1862, lot 185 (15s. to the dealer Francis Harvey); George A. Smith no later than 1876; sold from Smith's collection, Christie's, 16 July 1880, lot 101 (£2.10s. to the dealer John Pearson); Thomas Glenn Arthur no later than 1890; sold from Arthur's collection, Christie's, 20 March 1914, lot 52 (£14.14s. to the dealer Frank T. Sabin); the dealer Robson & Co.; sold July 1923 by Robson to the dealer Charles Sessler ($407); sold by Sessler to Henry E. Huntington in Aug. 1923 for $1500.

desc.objtitle:
Lucifer and the Pope in Hell,

objnote.p: The underlying etching and engraving in this impression is probably in the second state of two, although this cannot be determined with any certainty because the dense color printing from the surface of the plate almost completely covers the intaglio lines.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two figures stand just right of center in a landscape that depicts hell against a background of darkness. The rightmost figure, who likely represents the Pope and may be a caricature of King George III, stands facing forward or walking to the left but turns his head to look to the right. He wears a three-tiered spiky hat or crown and a long gown. His brow is furrowed and he frowns slightly. His left arm is raised and bent in front of his chest, where the figure at left may hold his left hand (which is not visible). The figure at left stands, hovers, or walks behind the Pope and faces forward while looking slightly right. His left foot is raised and extended backward at right. He has short hair that stands on end, and his blue body appears to be scaly and nude except for a long cape. This figure likely represents Lucifer. His right arm is raised horizontally and extended to the right. In his right hand, he holds a spear horizontally with its tip pointed left. His left arm is raised slightly and with his left hand he holds the Pope's left hand, as if leading him to the left. The ground on which the central pair walks may be water or earth(?). What appears to be a pit of fire with seven figures inside is visible in the lower left corner of the composition. The three with crowns are probably kings. We see little more than the open mouth of the first figure on the left. Only the top half of the head of the second figure from the left is visible and faces forward. The heads and upper bodies of the third, fourth, and fifth figures from the left in the pit are visible. The third figure faces forward but turns his head to look right and up. He has long hair and a beard; his mouth is open. His right arm is raised and bent to the right with palm facing down. A serpent coils around his right arm and torso. The fourth figure from the left faces forward and left with his head raised slightly to look up. He has short curly hair and a beard; he wears a spiky crown and his mouth is open. His left arm may be at his side; alternatively, the large body of a serpent may wrap around his left side torso and extend to the right. The fifth figure from the left also wears a spiky crown and has short hair that stands on end. He also has a long beard. This figure faces forward and right with wide eyes and a frown. He may look toward the standing pair at right. Two final heads are clearly visible against the far right side of the pit of fire. The head of the sixth figure from the left faces forward and leans to the left. One (closed?) eye is visible. The seventh head from the left faces forward and up, perhaps with an open mouth, to look toward the standing pair above. Tall flames and dark smoke rise behind the figures in the pit.
